questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the following device?
questions.solution:
The device shown is a tracheostomy tube. This is a tube that is inserted through the neck into the trachea to provide an airway. It is used for patients with acute upper airway obstruction, prolonged mechanical ventilation, and other conditions.

Other options :

  • Pulmonary toilet: Pulmonary toilet is the process of clearing mucus and other secretions from the lungs. It is important for patients with respiratory problems, such as COPD or cystic fibrosis.
  • Upper airway assessment: Upper airway assessment is the process of evaluating the upper airway for abnormalities. It is often performed in patients with sleep apnea or other breathing problems.
  • Prolonged mechanical ventilation: Tracheostomy tubes are commonly used in patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation to facilitate long-term airway management and weaning from the ventilator.

questions.text: Steeple sign on X-ray neck AP view is seen in?
questions.solution:
The "steeple sign" on an X-ray of the neck (AP view) is indicative of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup. Croup is characterized by inflammation of the upper airway, specifically the larynx and trachea, leading to narrowing of the subglottic region and causing the characteristic steeple-like appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis causes inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, which leads to a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

C. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition where the soft tissues of the larynx collapse during inspiration, causing a characteristic "omega-shaped" epiglottis on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

D. Laryngeal web: A laryngeal web is a congenital condition where there is a membrane or web-like structure across the larynx, which may cause respiratory difficulty, but it does not result in the steeple sign on X-ray.

questions.text: Name the maneuver shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Epley's maneuver

The image shows the Epley maneuver, which is a therapeutic maneuver used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The Epley maneuver involves a series of head and body movements to reposition the displaced calcium crystals (otoconia) within the inner ear.

Other options:

A. Brandt-Daroff maneuver - The Brandt-Daroff maneuver is another therapeutic exercise used to treat BPPV. It involves sitting on the edge of a bed and performing a specific set of movements to reposition the otoconia.

C. Foster maneuver - The Foster maneuver is used for self-administration of canalith repositioning for BPPV involving the posterior semicircular canal.

D. Semont maneuver - The Semont maneuver is another canalith repositioning maneuver used to treat BPPV.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option B: Laryngeal papilloma: Usually it is a single in size, less aggressive and doesnot recur after surgical removal. It is common in the age group of 30-5-yrs and usualy arises from the anterior half of the vocal cord or the anterior commissure as in the above image.

Option A: Reinke's oedema: it occurs due to collection of the oedema fluid in the sub-epithelial space of reinke, usual cause is vocal abuse and smoking. Both the vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swelling.

Option C: Malignancy: Malignant lesions of the vocal cord may appear as irregular masses or ulcerations but usually don't present as exophytic lesions.

Option D: Tracheomalacia: It refers to the weekening of the tracheal cartilage which may cause the tracheal collapse during respiration and is not evident in the above image.

questions.text: Tubercular otitis media is characterized by all except
questions.solution:
Tubercular otitis media is characterized by multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane, pale granulations, and foul-smelling ear discharge. Painful otorrhea is not a typical feature of tubercular otitis media.

Other options and why they are wrong:

B. Multiple perforations: Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane are a characteristic feature of tubercular otitis media due to the destructive nature of the disease.

C. Pale granulations: Tubercular otitis media is associated with pale or edematous granulations due to the chronic inflammatory process.

D. Foul-smelling ear discharge: Foul-smelling or purulent ear discharge is commonly observed in tubercular otitis media due to the chronic infection.

questions.text: All of the following are smell perception tests except?
questions.solution:
D. Arnold stick test

The Arnold's nerve ear-cough reflex test, also known as the Arnold stick test, is a neurological examination that uses a cotton swab on a stick to trigger a cough

The test can help diagnose neurological conditions. It's an example of hypersensitivity of the vagal afferent nerves, which can be a sign of a sensory neuropathy of the vagus nerve

A. Smell diskettes

Smell diskettes are small, disposable disks that contain a variety of different odors.

The patient is asked to smell the diskettes and identify the odors. This test is a measure of the patient's ability to smell.

B. UP-SIT

UP-SIT stands for Upper Airway Resistance Sensitivity Index Test. This test is used to assess the resistance of the upper airway to airflow.

The test is performed by measuring the pressure drop across the upper airway when the patient breathes in and out.

C. CC-SIT

CC-SIT stands for Conductance Change Sensitivity Index Test. This test is also used to assess the resistance of the upper airway to airflow.

The test is performed by measuring the change in conductance of the upper airway when the patient breathes in and out.

questions.text: What is the structure being shown with the arrow in the given CT SCAN image?
questions.solution:
The structure shown with the arrow in the CT scan image is: Onodi cell

The Onodicell, also known as the sphenoethmoidal cell, is a type of paranasal sinus cell that is located posteriorly and superiorly to the sphenoid sinus. It is located just above the sphenoid sinus and can be closely related to important structures such as the optic nerve and carotid artery.

B. Agger nasi: The agger nasi cell is located anteriorly to the ethmoid sinus, near the frontal recess, and is not represented by the arrow in the image.

C. Concha bullosa: Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate, and it is not the structure shown in the image.

D. Haller cell: Haller cell is an infraorbital ethmoid air cell and is not represented by the arrow in the image.

questions.text: Which is the most common source of bleeding during tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
A. Paratonsillar vein: After tonsillectomy (tonsil surgery), postoperative bleeding can occur, and the bleeding source is commonly the paratonsillar vein (peritonsillar vein). The paratonsillar vein is located near the tonsils and can be a site of bleeding following tonsil surgery. Post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage is a known complication, and the bleeding often originates from this vein.

B. External palatine vein: This is a less likely source of bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils.

C. Ascending pharyngeal artery: This is less likely to cause bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils and is a larger vessel.

D. Facial artery: This is less likely to cause bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils and is a larger vessel.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a patient who underwent laryngectomy. Which mode of speech is he using?
questions.solution: In the image, a laryngectomy has been performed, which means the patient's larynx (voice box) has been removed. In such cases, patients often use alternative methods to produce speech. Tracheoesophageal speech is a common method used by laryngectomy patients. It involves the surgical creation of a small opening between the trachea and the esophagus, through which air can be redirected from the lungs into the esophagus. By expelling air from the esophagus, patients can produce speech sounds and communicate.

questions.text: Identify the nerve block in the following figure:
questions.solution:
The nerve block shown in the picture above is to block nasociliary nerve.

To block the nasociliary nerve, or it's branches, 3cm, 25 G needle is inserted 1 cm above inner canthus and directed posterolaterally keeping contact with bone.

questions.text: Which of the following airway obstruction level causes inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution: Stridor means noisy breathing. It is due to airway obstruction. Depending on the level of obstruction, it is of three types.

questions.solution: Cricothyroid muscle is supplied by external branch of superior laryngeal nerve. Rest all laryngeal muscles which move the vocal cord are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Montgomery's silicon T - tube is used in which of the following surgical procedure?
questions.solution: Montgomery's silicon T tube is used for laryngotracheal reconstruction in congenital subglottic stenosis. This tube is used to support the reconstructed segment for 6 weeks.

Does not assess the mucosal wave form of vocal cord on phonation

VF - vocal fold

Supraglottic extension is not a contraindication for partial laryngectomy.

Fixed cords - implies stage T3

questions.text: Which of the following describes Type II cordectomy correctly
questions.solution:
Subligamental cordectomy - Type II cordectomy

  • Resection of the epithelium, Reinke's space and the vocal ligament
  • For glottic carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are helpful in the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea except -
questions.solution:
Muller's manoeuvre -

  • An endoscope is used to look for collapse of soft tissues in the oropharynx when the patient inspires vigorously.
  • Level of pharyngeal obstruction can be found.
  • It plays a role in the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea but has no role in its treatment.

Treatment options for OSA include -

A. Lifestyle changes

  • Weight loss
  • Quit alcohol and smoking
  • Dietary modification

B. Positional therapy- Sleeping on the side as supine position may cause OSA.

C. CPAP(Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) or BiPAP(bilevel positive airway pressure) when CPAP is not tolerated. These devices maintain a positive pressure and keep the airway open.

D. Surgical-Laser Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty(UPPP) - The aim is to increase the size of airway.

questions.text: All of these constitute the Waldeyer's ring except
questions.solution:
Submental lymph nodes are not a part of Waldeyer's ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer's ring.

Includes -

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil or the adenoid
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules(in posterior pharyngeal wall).

questions.text: All of the following are used for tonsillectomy except:
questions.solution:
Suction diathermy is a method of adenoidectomy.

Others are methods of tonsillectomy.

choices.text: Cellulitis of floor of the mouth
Aphthous ulcers in the floor of Mouth

questions.text: 'Ludwig's angina' is characterized by all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcers are recurrent and superficial, usually involving movable mucosa, i.e., inner surfaces of lips, buccal mucosa, tongue, floor of mouth and soft palate, while sparing mucosa of the hard palate and gingivae.

Ludwig's Angina :

  • Infection of submandibular space(sublingual space + submaxillary spaces) or floor of mouth. It is mainly Cellulitis.
  • Dental Infections account for 80% of the cases. Roots of premolars cause sublingual space infection while roots of the molar teeth cause submaxillary space infection
  • Mixed infections involving aerobes and anaerobes is seen.

questions.text:
Deformities occurring in leprosy patients are:

a. Facies leonina
b. Low set ears
c. Saddle nose
d. Lagophthalmos
questions.solution:
Low set ears and micrognathia are not seen in leprosy patients.

The deformities occurring in leprosy patients are -

  • Facies Leonia
  • Saddle nose - due to depression of bridge of nose
  • Lagopthalmos - due to facial nerve involvement

questions.text: Treatment of choice for the polyp shown in the CT scan is?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows a homogenous mass in one maxillary sinus and ipsilateral nasal cavity. So antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) is the most likely diagnosis.

The treatment of choice for antrochoanal polyp is FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery). If unavailable, endoscopic polypectomy can be done.

Intranasal polypectomy and Caldwell Luc operations were done previously for antrochoanal polyp.

Intranasal ethmoidectomy was done previously for ethmoidal polyp.

All these are superseded by endoscopic surgeries now.

questions.text: Lautenschlaeger's operation is indicated for?
questions.solution:
Atrophic rhinitis can be managed medically and surgically.

SURGICAL MANAGEMENT INCLUDES -

  • Young's operation→ Complete closure of both nostrils. They are opened after 6 months.
  • Modified Young's operation→ Partial closure of nostrils leaving behind a 3mm hole.
  • Lautenschlaeger technique→ Narrowing of nasal cavities by medial displacement of lateral wall of nose

choices.text: Arises from upper part of nasal septum

questions.text: All statements are true about Ringertz tumour of Nose except
questions.solution:
Ringertz tumor arises from lateral wall of nose.

Inverted Papilloma (Transitional Cell Papilloma or Ringertz Tumour or Schneiderian Papilloma)

  • It is a tumour of the non-olfactory mucosa of nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.
  • Most common site of origin is lateral wall of nose in the middle meatus
  • It is a benign but locally invasive tumour and can show malignant conversion.
  • Human papilloma virus is thought to be responsible for its aetiology.
  • Clinically, men are affected more than women in the age group of 40-70.
  • Treatment - Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. These days endoscopic approach is preferred.
  • Radiotherapy is not advised as it may induce malignancy.

questions.text: Facies leprosa is characterised by all except:
questions.solution:
Nodules on face are not a feature of facies leprosa.

Facies leprosa -

  • Seen in lepromatous leprosy
  • Characterized by the resorption of the nasal bone, anterior nasal spine, supra-incisive alveolar region, and anterior alveolar process of the maxilla, with associated sensory or motor damage depending on the type of nerves involved.

choices.text: Sensorineural deafness is a common feature
Red bulging tympanic membrane is a common otoscopic finding
Tympanostomy tubes are usually required for treatment
Ear ache is a common symptom

questions.text: The most common site of cholesteatoma in the middle ear cleft is
questions.solution: Prussak's space is the most common site of cholesteatoma formation in middle ear. It lies between the pars flaccida and the neck of malleus.

questions.text: Which is the diagnostic investigation of choice in assessing hearing loss in children?
questions.solution:
BERA (brainstem evoked response audiometry) is to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain. In this method, electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz. ABR is used:

  1. As a screening procedure for infants.
  2. To determine the threshold of hearing in infants; also in children and adults who do not cooperate and in malingerers.
  3. To diagnose retrocochlear pathology particularly acoustic neuroma.
  4. To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumours.
  5. To monitor CN VIII intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuromas to preserve the function of cochlear nerve.

A patient with recurrent episodes of facial paralysis has following findings on examination of oral cavity


What is the name of this entity?
questions.solution:
Melkersson Rosenthal Syndrome Consists of Triad of

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of wrist with a lesion in a female 25 years old. Identify the same.
questions.solution:
The x ray shows an expansile epiphyseal lytic lesion in the distal ulna with soap bubble appearance. This is the classical finding of GCT. The age of the patient is also consistent as GCT is seen between 20 and 40 years of age.

It cannot be osteosarcoma as it is seen in commonly patients less than 20 years and arises from the metaphysis.

Chondroblastoma arises from the epiphysis but is seen in children.

It is very rare of dermoid cyst to involve bones, even if it does, it involves the skull.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not associated with Ulnar Nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Tests Not Associated with Ulnar Nerve Injury

The test that is not associated with ulnar nerve injury among the options provided is:

D. Phalen's test

Phalen's test is used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves compression of the median nerve at the wrist. It is not specifically related to ulnar nerve injury.

The other tests mentioned are associated with ulnar nerve injury:

A. Book test (also known as Froment's sign or test) is used to assess the function of the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve. It involves asking the patient to hold a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger while the examiner tries to pull it away. If the ulnar nerve is injured, the thumb will flex at the interphalangeal joint due to the weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle

B. Egawa test is not a commonly known test. It is likely referring to the Egawa sign, which is the inability to cross the middle and index fingers due to weakness of the interossei muscles, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve

C. Card test is not a standard test for ulnar nerve injury. It may be a variation of the book test (Froment's sign), but it is not a widely recognized term.

In summary, while the book test (Froment's sign), Egawa sign, and other tests are associated with ulnar nerve injury, D. Phalen's test is specifically used for carpal tunnel syndrome and is not related to ulnar nerve dysfunction.

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6952870/

questions.text: Identify the cast shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Patellar Tendon Bearing Cast

The cast shown in the image is a Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) cast.

The PTB cast is a type of below-knee cast that extends from just below the knee to the toes. It is designed to distribute weight-bearing forces through the patellar tendon and tibial tuberosity, rather than directly on the distal tibia. This helps to prevent skin breakdown and allows for early weight-bearing in certain lower extremity injuries or conditions.

Key features of a PTB cast include:

Extending from just below the knee to the toes

Incorporating a window over the patellar tendon and tibial tuberosity

Allowing for weight-bearing through the patellar tendon

The other options can be ruled out as follows:

  1. Below knee cast is a more general term that encompasses various types of casts from the knee to the toes, without the specific PTB design.
  2. Above knee cast extends from the groin to the toes and is not applicable here.
  3. Cylinder cast is a type of long leg cast that immobilizes the knee in extension, which is different from the PTB cast.

Therefore, based on the characteristic features visible in the image, the cast shown is a Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) cast.

questions.text: A 12 year old child presented with injury to his right wrist after a fall. His x ray is given below. Identify the type of physeal injury according to the Salter Harris classification.
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided regarding the 12-year-old child with a wrist injury, the type of physeal injury according to the Salter-Harris classification is:

B. Type 2.

A Salter-Harris Type II fracture is characterized by a fracture that extends through the growth plate (physis) and exits through the metaphysis, often leaving a triangular fragment of the metaphysis known as the Thurston-Holland fragment. This type is the most common among Salter-Harris fractures, accounting for approximately 75% of cases.

In contrast:

Type I involves a fracture that runs directly through the physis without involving the metaphysis.

Type III involves a fracture that goes through the physis and into the epiphysis.

Type IV involves a fracture that traverses through both the metaphysis and the epiphysis, affecting the growth plate.

choices.text: DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
It is defined as T score less than 2.5.
Bisphosphonates are the drug of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding osteoporosis is false?
questions.solution:
False Statement about Osteoporosis

The false statement regarding osteoporosis among the options provided is:

C. It is defined as T score less than 2.5.

This statement is false because the World Health Organization (WHO) defines osteoporosis as a bone mineral density (BMD) T-score of -2.5 or lower at the femoral neck, total hip, or lumbar spine by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA).

The other statements are true:

A. Osteoporosis is seen commonly in postmenopausal females. The risk of osteoporosis increases significantly after menopause due to decreased estrogen levels, which play a crucial role in maintaining bone health.

B. DEXA scan is the investigation of choice. DXA is considered the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis and assessing fracture risk. It provides a reliable measurement of BMD at various skeletal sites, including the spine and hip.

D. Bisphosphonates are the drug of choice. Bisphosphonates are the first-line pharmacological treatment for osteoporosis. They work by inhibiting bone resorption, leading to increased bone density and reduced fracture risk.

Therefore, the false statement is C. It is defined as T score less than 2.5, as the correct definition of osteoporosis by WHO criteria is a T-score of -2.5 or lower.

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1126783/

questions.text: What is not required in an emergency management of an open femur fracture?
questions.solution:
Open reduction and internal fixation is not done on emergency basis in cases of open fractures. First fracture should be stabilized with external fixator and wound should be debrided.

Once wound gets healed and infection is cleared thereafter open reduction and internal fixation is done.

For open fractures gustilo and Anderson classification is used for grading.

For open fractures like 3B antibiotics coated intramedullary nails are preferred over K wires.

  • With the evolution of available nails like antibiotic impregnated nails, intramedullary nailing is now performed even in 3B fractures.
  • Although there was initial phobia for the use of intramedullary nails, their usage has become widespread not only in grade 1 and 2 but even in grade 3 injuries.

questions.text: Most common pattern of Pott's spine involvement is?
questions.solution:
There are 4 patterns of vertebral involvement in Pott's spine:

  1. Paradiscal (due to arterial spread):- This is the commonest  In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.
  2. Central (due to venous spread):- In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal.
  3. Anterior (due to subperisteal spread):- In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  4. Appendiceal and posterior type (occur in isolation involving pedicles, laminae, transverse process and spinous process or in conjunction with typical paradiscal variant).

questions.text: Named fractures match the following:
questions.solution:
March fracture: Fatigue fracture of the shaft of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.

Bennett's fracture-dislocation: It is an oblique, intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the trapezio-metacarpal joint

Jone's fracture: Avulsion fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal.

Boxers' fracture: It is a ventrally displaced fracture through the neck of the 5th metacarpal, usually occurs in boxers

questions.text: Three bony point is maintained in which fracture?
questions.solution:
• Three bony point relationship: This is an important sign. It is helpful in diagnosing different traumatic conditions around the elbow.
  • With the elbow in 90o flexion, the three bony points around the elbow i.e., the medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle and tip of the olecranon form a near-isosceles triangle.
  • The base of the triangle is formed by the line joining the two epicondyles and the apex by the tip of the olecranon.
  • In a supracondylar fracture the relationship of three bony points is maintained (normal).
  • In posterior dislocation of the elbow, the triangle is reversed.
  • In intercondylar fractures of the elbow, and in malunited fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus, the base of the triangle is broadened.

Three bony points relationship. (a) Medial epicondyle, (b) Lateral epicondyle, (c) Tip of olecranon

questions.text: Identify the structure marked on the x ray.
questions.solution:
Based on the provided X-ray image, the structure marked is: B. Posterior rib

  • The image shows a chest X-ray, likely in a posterior-anterior (PA) projection, where the X-ray beam travels from the posterior (back) to the anterior (front) of the patient.
  • In a PA projection, the posterior ribs are seen superimposed on the anterior ribs, forming a single rib shadow on the X-ray image.
  • The marked structure corresponds to the posterior portion of the rib, which is visible due to the PA projection.

The other options are incorrect:

  • A. Anterior rib: The anterior portion of the rib is not visible as a separate structure in a PA projection.
  • C. Costal cartilage: Costal cartilage is not visible on a plain radiograph, as it is not well-visualized due to its soft tissue density.
  • D. Right descending pulmonary artery: The marked structure is clearly a rib and not a vascular structure like the pulmonary artery.

Therefore, the correct identification of the marked structure on the chest X-ray is B. Posterior rib.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3529706/

questions.text: Which of the following emergency treatment measures is most important in preventing infection?
questions.solution:
Factors for preventing post operative infection in case of open fracture

  1. Proper surgical debridement
  2. Duration of surgery from time of injury
  3. Proper saline wash during and before surgery
  4. Proper antibiotic coverage
  5. Duration of surgery
  6. Mechanism of injury and severity of soft tissue injury
  7. Type of wound
  8. Post operative dressing and its material

questions.text: Clostridium perfringens toxin which causes myonecrosis is
questions.solution: • The major toxins used for strain classification of clostridium perfringens are alpha toxin, beta toxin, epsilon toxin, and iota toxin. Alfa toxin is responsible for hemolysis, myonecrosis and gas gangrene in the infected tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is most abundant in bone?
questions.solution: Cells of bone

choices.text: Risk of pathological fracture after metastasis

questions.text: For evaluation of which of the following condition is Mirel's criteria used for ?
questions.solution:
• Pathological fracture occurs in a bone which is abnormally weak either by systemic affection or by a localized disease. Trivial trauma/stress which would have left the normal bone intact can cause pathological fracture in weak bone. Osteoporosis is the most common cause of pathological fracture in elderly.
  • Causes of pathological fracture are-
    1. Reduced bone mass: Osteoporosis
    2. Neoplastic: Primary bone tumor (benign and malignant), metastatic bone lesions.
    3. Tumor-like lesions: Simple bone cyst, aneurysmal bone cyst, fibrous dysplasia, non-ossifying fibroma
    4. Metabolic and hormonal imbalance: Osteomalacia, rickets, scurvy, Cushing's syndrome, hyperparathyroidism
    5. Developmental disorders and bony dysplasias: Osteogenesis imperfecta, osteopetrosis, achondroplasia, diaphyseal aclasis (multiple exostosis), Ollier's disease
    6. Defect of bone remodeling: Paget's disease, osteopetrosis
    7. Infections: Osteomyelitis, hydatid disease of bone
    8. Marrow cell disorders: Histiocytosis, Gaucher's disease.
  • When a bone develops a metastatic lesion, there is a high chance that the bone can fracture. We however do not want a fracture to occur as this will result is nonunion which is very resistant to treatment. Moreover the patient will also have to suffer pain and poor function on the affected limb. So we try and prevent fracture by nailing a bone with a lytic lesion. This procedure is called prophylactic fixation. There is a criteria, which helps us decide what lesions should be fixed prophylactically and what lesions can be left alone. This is called MIREL's score. A Mirel's score more than 8 is an indication for prophylactic fixation.

questions.text: Anterior cruciate ligament acts by preventing which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The primary function of ACL is to prevent anterior translation of tibia with respect to femur.
  • ACL takes origin from medial wall of lateral femoral condyle (posteriorly in the area of the inter-condylar notch) and courses anteriorly and medially to insert on the inter-condylar area of the tibia.
  • The ACL is critically important because it prevents the tibia from being pushed too far anterior relative to the femur. It is often torn during twisting or hyperextension injuries of the knee.
  • ACL tear is treated with ACL reconstruction. ACL reconstruction is most commonly done using autograft, meaning, the tissue used for repair is taken from the patient's body itself. The two most common sources for tissue are the patellar tendon and hamstrings tendon.
  • The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) stretches from medial condyle of femur to the posterior intercondylar area.
  • This ligament prevents posterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur.

questions.text: Vascular sign of Narath is not seen in
questions.solution:
• Vascular sign of Narath: inability to feel femoral pulse against femoral head in the inguinal region.
    • It is positive in all conditions where the femoral head is not present in its normal position. Eg. Traumatic hip dislocation, DDH, Tom Smith arthritis and Girdlestone arthroplasty
  • Useful signs in orthopedics
    • VIC: Volkmann's sign
    • Piano key sign: Distal radio ulnar joint instability (e.g., Madelung deformity, Malunited colles fracture etc.)
    • De Quervain's syonvitis: Finkelstein test
    • Flexor tenosynovitis: Kanavel's signs
    • AVN hip: Sectoral sign
    • Iliopsoas tendonitis: Ludloff sign

questions.text: Which of the following is feature of osteoarthritis of knee joint?
questions.solution:
• Radiological features of osteoarthritis
    • Joint space reduction (due to loss of cartilage)
    • Osteophytes formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis (due to condensation of trabeculae)
    • Subchondral cyst formation (due to osteonecrosis and seeping of synovial fluid into cracks)

questions.text: Earliest radiological sign in RA?
questions.solution:
• Radiological findings in RA
    1. Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    2. Reduced joint space
    3. Erosion of articular margins
    4. Subchondral cysts
    5. Juxta-articular osteopenia
    6. Deformities of the hand and fingers

questions.text: Chronic fluorosis is caused by drinking water with fluoride content of
questions.solution:
• Chronic fluorosis is seen in localities where the water supply contains > 10 ppm fluoride (Davidson).
  • Fluorosis It is characterized by excessive deposition of calcium in bone & soft tissues due to increased intake of fluorides through drinking water.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dental fluorosis - earliest sign of fluorosis (mottling of enamel) - MC involve the incisors of upper jaw.
    • Skeletal fluorosis - pain in back & joints, stiff spine, paranesthesia, spastic paraparesis & anemia.
  • Radiological findings:
    • Spine: Calcification of posterior longitudinal ligament.
    • Pelvis: Calcification of ischio pubic & sacroiliac ligaments
    • Forearm & leg: calcification of interosseous membrane.
  • Treatment: Defluridation of water (Nalgonda technique)

questions.text: Gaenslen's test is used to identify which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Gaenslen's test is used for the diagnosis of sacroiliitis. The only cause of sacroilitis among the options is Ankylosing spondylosis. The signs and tests for sacroiliitis include:
    1. Tenderness localized to posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) (as PSIS overlies SI joints)
    2. SI side-to-side compression test: The patient is in the side lying position and the examiner's hands are placed over the upper part of the iliac crest, press- ing toward the floor. The movement causes strain in the SI joint. Positive test is indicated by pain in the SI joint.
    3. Gaenslen's test: The patient lies on his or her back, the examiner maximally flexes the hip on the normal side (by pushing the knee towards patient chest) and extends the affected hip (by allowing it to fall over the side of the table). The test is considered positive if the patient complains of pain over the SI joint.
    4. Pump handle test: The patient lies supine; the examiner grasps the affected side knee of the patients with one hand and flexes the knee and hip and forces it toward the opposite shoulder across the chest. Pain over involved SI joints indicates a positive test.
    5. Patric test/FABER test: The test is performed by keeping the limb flexed, abducted and externally rotated (FABER). If pain is elicited on the ipsilateral side anteriorly, it is suggestive of hip joint pathology of same side. If pain is elicited on the contralateral side posteriorly around the SI joint, it is suggestive of pain arising from SI joint.

choices.text: Decreased Ca, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase
Increased Ca, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase
Decreased Ca and phosphate but increased alkaline phosphatase
Normal Ca, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase

questions.text: What is the biochemical analysis in osteoporosis?
questions.solution: Osteoporosis is a condition where the total bone mass or bone density is reduced. It is a quantitative deficiency of bone; however, the quality of bone is very good. Hence, there is no biochemical abnormality in osteoporosis.

questions.text: Weakest portion of shoulder joint capsule is
questions.solution:
• Shoulder is weakest inferiorly but dislocates anteriorly because it is the direction of force that decides the dislocation but never the anatomical weakness for a particular joint, e.g., the force that causes anterior dislocation (Abduction and external rotation) is much more common as in throwing objects like ball or javelin as compared to force that causes inferior dislocation.
  • Most common type of shoulder dislocation-Anterior > Posterior >Inferior (Luxatio Erecta)
  • Most common subtype of anterior shoulder dislocation-Sub coracoid> Sub glenoid
  • Most common subtype of posterior shoulder dislocation-Sub acromial
  • Most common acute complication of shoulder dislocation-Axillary nerve injury 
  • Most common (overall) complication of shoulder dislocation-Recurrent dislocation
  • Most common lesion leading to recurrent shoulder dislocation-Bankart lesion
  • Most common complication of proximal humeral fractures-stiffness
  • The most common nerve injured in fracture shaft of humerus-radial nerve palsy
  • The most common cause of non-union in fracture shaft of humerus distraction at the fracture site

questions.text: Housemaids knee is bursitis of
questions.solution:
Given below are the common named bursitis of the body.

  1. Prepatellar bursitis - Housemaid's knee
  2. Infrapatellar bursitis - Clergyman's knee
  3. Olecranon bursitis - Student's elbow
  4. Ischial bursitis - Weaver's bottom
  5. On lateral malleolus - Tailor's ankle
  6. On great toe - Bunion

questions.text: Most common site of stress fracture -
questions.solution: • The most common site of stress fracture is the tibia followed by the 2nd metatarsal (March fracture). As the tibia is not in the options, the next best choice is 2nd metatarsal.

questions.text: The anterior approach to total hip arthroplasty requires dissection between which of the following muscle planes?
questions.solution:
The anterior approach to the hip joint involves identifying the plane between the tensor fascia lata and the sartorius muscles.

In the anterolateral approach to hip, we use the plane between TFL and Gluteus medius.

questions.text: Identify x-ray view taken in below image?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph is that of open mouth view or Odontoid view.

Jefferson fracture(of C1 vertebra) and odontoid fractures can be radiologically diagnosed with an open mouth view. Fracture of the atlas, the patient usually presents with neck pain but no neurological deficit.

Swimmer's View is a lateral radiograph view used to visualise C7-T1 junction.

Water's View is nose-chin position view(also called occipitomental view) used to visualise the Paranasal sinuses.

Schuller's View is the lateral oblique view to visualise mastoid and temporal bone with X-ray beam projected 30 degree to the sagittal.

questions.text: Night pains are characteristically seen with
questions.solution:
Osteoid osteoma:

  • Benign bone forming lesion considered to be the most common true benign tumor of the bone
  • Age group - 2nd-3rd decades
  • Male:female 3:1
  • Lower extremity, long bones, Posterior elements spine, Diaphyseal/metaphyseal
  • Pain - worse at night
  • X-RAY - Cortical radiolucent nidus <1.5 cm with marked cortical thickening
  • High levels of cyclooxygenases and prostaglandins in the lesion
  • Frequently responds to NSAIDs
  • HISTOLOGY - Trabeculae surrounded by loose fibrovascular tissue
  • TREATMENT - NSAIDs, Burr down technique, Radiofrequency ablation.

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital long bone deficiency in humans?
questions.solution:
• Fibular hemimelia is the most common congenital long bone deficiency in humans.
  • It is the Partial/complete absence of fibula
  • Clinical features
    • Absent/short fibula
    • Short tibia
    • Anteromedial bowing of tibia

questions.text: Indicators of poor prognosis in the pott's spine is/are:
questions.solution:
Factors leading to

  • poor prognosis in potts spine:
    • Inactive disease with poor mechanical compression
    • Complete paralysis/Complete cord involvement
    • Paralysis for more than 1year
    • Presence of severe kyphosis(>60 degree)
    • Older age and poor nutrition
    • Healed vertebral lesion
    • Presence of myelomalacia and syringomyel ia on magnetic resonance imaging(MRI).
  • Good prognosis is associated with:
    • Inflammatory cause of cord involvement
    • Incomplete involvement
    • Short duration of deficit
    • Minimal kyphotic deformity
    • Younger age
    • Good nutritional status.

questions.text: Joint erosion is not seen in
questions.solution:
• Most inflammatory/infective arthritis produces erosions in the articular surface, hence called erosive arthritis.
  • Examples of erosive arthritis are
    • RA
    • Septic arthritis
    • TB
    • Psoriatic arthritis
  • However, there is an exception to this rule. SLE (Jaccoud arthropathy) produces non - erosive arthritis

questions.text: There is a history of village people consuming a crop as a staple diet. Many of the villagers are now presenting with paresis and are using a stick to stand. Which of the following vitamins would help?
questions.solution:
This is a case of "Osteolathyrism"

γ -glutamyl-β-aminopropionitrile(BAPN), a glutamine derivative of ß-aminopropionitrile in Lathyrus (Khesari dal) is a known osteolathyrogen. Vit C is protective against the effects of this molecule by strengthening the Collagen

Option A: Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness. The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment to adapt to dim light, then night blindness, an inability to see in the dark.

More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia: keratinization of the cornea and blindness. Vitamin A also has an important role in differentiation of immune system cells, and even mild deficiency leads to increased susceptibility to infectious diseases. The synthesis of retinol-binding protein, which is required to transport the vitamin in the bloodstream, is reduced in response to infection(it is a negative acute phase protein), decreasing the circulating concentration of the vitamin and further impairing immune responses.

Option B: In the vitamin D deficiency disease rickets, the bones of children are under mineralized as a result of poor absorption of calcium. Similar problems occur as a result of deficiency during the adolescent growth spurt. Osteomalacia in adults results from the demineralization of bone, especially in women who have little exposure to sunlight, especially after several pregnancies.

Option C: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy. Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen. Both this enzyme requires vitamin C. So signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis(leading to delayed wound healing) and psychological changes that can be attributed to impaired synthesis of catecholamines.

Option D: Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding.

So This patient is likely to have Vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in glomerular basement membrane:
questions.solution:
Option A & Option B: The keratan sulfates consist of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units containing sulfate attached to the 6′position of GlcNAc or occasionally of Gal. Keratan sulfate I was originally isolated from the cornea, while keratan sulfate II came from cartilage. The two GAGs differ in the structural links to the core proteins and as I or II, the classification is based on the different linkage to the core protein. In the eye, they lie between collagen fibrils and play a critical role in corneal transparency. Changes in proteoglycan composition found in corneal scars disappear when the cornea heals.

Option C: Heparan Sulfate is present in a proteoglycan found on many extracellular cell surfaces. It contains GlcN with fewer N-sulfates than heparin and unlike heparin, its predominant uronic acid is GlcUA. Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells, with their core proteins actually spanning that membrane. In this, they may act as receptors and may also participate in the mediation of the cell growth and cell-cell communication. The attachment of cells to their substratum in culture is mediated at least in part by heparan sulfate. Heparan sulfate is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney along with type IV collagen and laminin, where it plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.

Option D: Proteoglycans linked to chondroitin sulfate by the Xyl-Ser O-glycosidic bond are prominent components of cartilage. The repeating disaccharide is similar to that found in hyaluronic acid, containing GlcUA but with GalNAc replacing GlcNAc. The GalNAc is substituted with sulfate at either its 4′ or its 6′ position, with approximately one sulfate being present per disaccharide unit. Chondroitin sulfates have an important role in maintaining the structure of the ECM. They are located at sites of calcification in endochondral bone and are a major component of cartilage. They are found in high amounts in the ECM of the central nervous system and in addition to their structural function, are thought to act as signaling molecules in the prevention of the repair of nerve endings after injury.

questions.text: Vitamin B12/cyanocobalamin is found in?
questions.solution:
Although vitamin B12 is synthesized exclusively by microorganisms, for practical purposes vitamin B12 is found only in foods of animal origin, there being no plant sources of this vitamin. This means that strict vegetarians(vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency. The small amounts of the vitamin formed by bacteria on the surface of fruits may be adequate to meet requirements, but preparations of vitamin B12 made by bacterial fermentation are available.

So Option A is correct.

questions.text: Norepinephrine to epinephrine requires which amino acid?
questions.solution:
Neural cells convert tyrosine to epinephrine and norepinephrine. DOPA decarboxylase(EC 4.1.1.28), a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme, forms dopamine. Subsequent hydroxylation, catalyzed by dopamine β-oxidase, then forms norepinephrine. In the adrenal medulla, phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase utilizes S-adenosyl methionine to methylate the primary amine of norepinephrine, forming epinephrine.

So Option C is the correct option.

questions.text: In which technique, labelled/tagging antibody is not used?
questions.solution:
Option A: In order to minimize exposure to radioactive materials, fluorescently labeled ligand or antibody is used in ELISA.

The sensitivity of enzyme assays can be exploited to detect proteins that lack catalytic activity. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays(ELISAs) use antibodies covalently linked to a "reporter enzyme" such as alkaline phosphatase or horseradish peroxidase whose products are readily detected, generally by the absorbance of light or by fluorescence. Serum or other biologic samples to be tested are placed in plastic, multiwell microtiter plates, where the proteins adhere to the plastic surface and are immobilized. Any exposed plastic that remains is subsequently "blocked" by adding a nonantigenic protein such as bovine serum albumin. A solution of antibody covalently linked to a reporter enzyme is then added. The antibodies adhere to the immobilized antigen and are themselves immobilized. Excess free antibody molecules are then removed by washing. The presence and quantity of bound antibodies is then determined by adding the substrate for the reporter enzyme and measuring the rate of its conversion to product.

In sandwich ELISA assay, two different antibodies against the ligand are used, each of which binds to a different region(epitope) of the analyte. The first antibody is covalently bound to the surface of each well of a multiple well plate and the sample is added and incubated. After removal of the incubation medium and washing each well, the second antibody is added, sandwiching the analyte between the two antibodies. The second antibody is labeled with a radioactive isotope or a fluorophore, thus permitting measurement of the bound second antibody and hence bound ligand. In some cases, the second antibody is labeled with an enzyme and measurement of bound second antibody and hence bound ligand, is by measurement of the activity of the enzyme that is now bound to the wall of each cell of the plate, after washing to remove unbound second antibody and adding an excess of the enzyme substrate.

Option B: ELISPOT assays bear many similarities to conventional sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays. A polyvinylidene difluoride(PVDF)-backed microplate is immobilized with an antibody specific for the analyte under evaluation. Immune cells are stimulated with an appropriate antigen or mitogen and then are pipetted into the wells of the microplate. The microplate is incubated in a humidified carbon dioxide(CO2) chamber at 37° C for a specified period of time, during which stimulated immune products, such as cytokines and antibodies, are secreted. The secreted analyte binds to the immobilized antibody on the microplate. The microplate is washed to remove cells and unbound substances and a biotinylated polyclonal antibody specific for the chosen analyte is added. Unbound biotinylated antibodies are removed by washing and streptavidin conjugated with alkaline phosphatase conjugate is added. Following another wash to remove unbound enzymes, the reaction is completed by the addition of the enzyme substrate solution(BCIP/NBT). Dark, blue-black precipitate spots mark the original locations of analyte-secreting cells. The spots can be counted manually under a stereomicroscope or automatically with a commercial automated ELISPOT reader system.


Option C: Immunofluorescence also used fluorescence labelled antibodies.

Option D: Heme-agglutination test

The nucleic acids of various viruses encode surface proteins(e.g.hemagglutinin(HA) of influenza virus) that agglutinate red blood cells(RBC) of a variety of species. The reaction of viral hemagglutinins with red blood cells results in a lattice of agglutinated cells that settle irregularly in a tube or microtiter well, a process known as hemagglutination. Non Agglutinated cells settle in a compact button.

So the heme agglutination test does not use labelled/tagging antibodies.

questions.text: DNA protein interaction can be studied by using:
questions.solution:
Option A: DNA fingerprinting is used to amplify and identify specific sequences of DNA. It is based on tandem repeats (TR) present in chromosomes. DNA cut with a different restriction enzyme to produce different patterns of restriction fragments. By electrophoretic separation of overlapping fragments, a restriction map is created. The study of restriction maps using suitable probes of short tandem repeats (STR) helps in developing DNA fingerprints.

Commonly used in forensic medicine to identify criminals and settle the disputes of parenthood of children. DNA can be isolated from stains on clothing made up of blood or semen or any body fluid, even several years before.

Option B: DNA footprinting used a collection of many methods to analyze protein DNA complexes and to identify the position of binding site.

Option C: Northern Blotting is used to detect specific RNA molecules.

Option D: ELISA is used to identify specific protein (antigen or antibody) by using enzyme labelled antibodies.

questions.text: A patient with thiamine deficiency develops acidosis, which of the following enzymes was affected?
questions.solution:
Option B: The role of thiamine diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency there is impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. In subjects on a relatively high carbohydrate diet, this results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, which may cause life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Option A & Option C: Pyruvate carboxylase & PEPCK involves gluconeogenesis.

Option D: Lactate dehydrogenase converts lactate into pyruvate, not involving thiamine.

questions.text: RNAi acts through?
questions.solution:
Targeted Gene Regulation by Disruption or Knockout, Knockin, Editing, and Controlled Expression

Various technical advances have allowed for the precise, targeted modification of mammalian genes. The exact methods used for genetically engineering mammalian genomes have evolved from tedious, low-efficiency methods based on positive and negative drug selections and homologous recombination (Knockout/Knockin) to the recently described CRISPR-Cas9 system. The goal of all of these methods is ultimately to generate a family of genetic variants of a gene of interest that are (a) a null, or complete loss-of-function allele; (b) recessive, loss-of-function alleles; and (c) ideally, dominant gain-of-function alleles. These genetic alterations are generated in pluripotent stem cells, which ultimately allow for introduction and propagation in whole model organisms (flys, fish, worms, rodents, etc). Having all three of these genetic variants allows one to precisely dissect the mechanism of action of any gene. However, complicating genetic analyses of many genes is the fact that their function(s) are essential for viability. To get around this problem, cell-type or tissue-specific genetic variants must be generated. This hurdle has been overcome through the use of cell- and tissue-specific enhancers that can drive the conditional (ie, experimentally controlled) expression of the targeting recombinases (ie, CRE-lox) and/or or nuclease (CRISPR-Cas9) that generate the altered genes, either null or loss- or gain-of-function alleles.

Alternatively, selected loss-of-function alleles can be generated through equivalent siRNA expression to knock down production of a specific gene product. Collectively, these methods allow for sophisticated genetic and biochemical tests of gene function and allow scientists to probe the structure and function of mammalian genes in physiologic contexts. Tremendous molecular mechanistic insights have been, and will continue to be, obtained into the molecular etiology of human disease through these and other biochemical approaches.

So option B is correct.

questions.text: Sideroblastic anemia treated by?
questions.solution:
Mutations in the gene encoding enzyme ALA synthase cause X-linked Sideroblastic anemia. It leads to anemia with decreased red cell counts and hemoglobin.

Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl-CoA and glycine in a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial δ-aminolevulinate synthase (ALA synthase.

Succinyl-CoA + glycine → δ-aminolevulinate + CoA-SH + CO2

Humans express two isozymes of ALA synthase. ALAS1 is ubiquitously expressed throughout the body, whereas ALAS2 is expressed in erythrocyte precursor cells. Formation of δ-aminolevulinate is rate-limiting for porphyrin biosynthesis in mammalian liver.

So Option A is correct.

questions.text: Ketone bodies are not utilised by liver because it lacks
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiokinase (also known as succinyl coenzyme A synthetase or succinate thiokinase) is an enzyme involved in citric acid cycle. It catalyzes the reversible reaction of succinyl-CoA to succinate.

Option B: Thiophorase is an enzyme involved in utilization of ketone bodies (Ketolysis). Liver actively produces ketone bodies, but it lacks enzyme Thiophorase, therefore liver is unable to use ketone bodies as fuel.

Steps of Ketolysis (Ketone body utilization)


Option C: Thiotransferase not involved in ketone body metabolism.

Option D: Thiolase is also involved in utilization of ketone bodies (Ketolysis) as well as in beta oxidation of fatty acid. It breakdown acetoacetyl CoA into two acetyl CoA.

questions.text: D galactose and D mannose are?
questions.solution:
• Diastereo-isomers of Glucose
    • Configurational changes with regard to C2, C3 and C4 will produce eight different monosaccharides.
    • Out of these, only 3 are seen in human body. They are Glucose, Galactose and Mannose.
  • Epimerism of Aldoses
    • When sugars are different from one another, only in configuration with regard to a single carbon atom, other than the reference carbon atom, they are called epimers. For example, glucose and mannose are an epimeric pair which differ only with respect to C2. Similarly, galactose is the 4th epimer of glucose.
    • Galactose and mannose are not epimers but diastereo-isomers.
  • Optical isomers - Enantiomers
    • With reference to the penultimate carbon atom (i.e. C5 in the case of glucose), the configuration of H and OH groups is changed and two mirror images are produced.
    • It may be noted that in D and L varieties, the groups in 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 5thcarbon atoms are totally reversed, so as to produce the mirror images.
    • D sugars are naturally occurring sugars and body can metabolize only D sugars.
  • Anomers
    • D-glucose has two anomers, alpha and beta varieties.
    • These anomers are produced by the spatial configuration with reference to the first carbon atom in aldoses and second carbon atom in ketoses. Hence, these carbon atoms are known as anomeric carbon atoms.
    • Alpha D Glucose and Beta D Glucose

Epimers are a subtype of diastereomers; diastereomers is a bigger class.

questions.text: Enzyme responsible for complete oxidation of glucose to CO2 and water is present in:
questions.solution:
• Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is taken up into mitochondria, and after oxidative decarboxylation to acetyl-CoA is oxidized to CO2 by the citric acid cycle
  • Under anaerobic conditions, pyruvate is reduced by the NADH to lactate, catalyzed by lactate

questions.text: Glucose transporter present in the RBC:
questions.solution:
• Highest level of GLUT1 is present in the RBC
  • Major Glucose transporter in brain is GLUT1 (not present in neurons)
  • Major Glucose transporter in the Placenta is GLUT 1
  • Major Glucose transporter in the RBC is GLUT1
  • Major neuronal Glucose transporter is GLUT3
  • Insulin-responsive glucose transporter is GLUT4, GLUT 8 and GLUT 12
  • Fructose transporter GLUT 5 (mainly) and GLUT 11
  • Urate transporter is GLUT 9
  • Glucose transporter in blastocyst is GLUT 8.

questions.text: All of the following statements about apoproteins are true Except:
questions.solution:
Apoprotein A-II and apo C-III inhibits lipoprotein lipase

Apoprotein C-II activates lipoprotein lipase

Apolipoproteins carry out several roles:

  1. They can form part of the structure of the lipoprotein, for example, apo B;
  2. They are enzyme cofactors, for example, C-II for lipoprotein lipase, A-I for lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase, or
  3. Enzyme inhibitors, for example, apo A-II and apo C-III for lipoprotein lipase, apo C-I for cholesteryl ester transfer protein; and
  4. They act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B-100 and apo E for the LDL receptor, apo E for the LDL-receptor-related protein-1 (LRP-1), which has been identified as the remnant receptor, and apo A-I for the HDL receptor.
  5. The functions of apo A-IV and apo D, however, are not yet clearly defined, although apo D is believed to be an important factor in human neurodegenerative disorders.

choices.text: Tail is made up of polymer of adenylate residues
Cap is made up of 7-guanosine triphosphate
Both help to maintain intracellular stability of mRNA

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding 5' cap and 3' tail of messenger RNA, except:
questions.solution:
Option A: 3'-hydroxyl terminus has an attached, non genetically encoded polymer of adenylate residues 20 to 250 nucleotides in length, known as Poly A tail.

Option B: Cap is made up of 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate, not only guanosine triphosphate.

Option C: Cap and tail both are added post transcriptionally as post transcriptional modifications.

Option D: The cap is involved in the recognition of mRNA by the translation machinery, and also helps stabilize the mRNA by preventing the nucleolytic attack by 5'-exoribonucleases. The poly(A) "tail" at the 3'-end of mRNAs maintains the intracellular stability of the specific mRNA by preventing the attack of 3'-exoribonucleases and also facilitates translation.

So both are involved in maintaining intracellular stability of mRNA.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes lead to synthesis of DNA from RNA?
questions.solution:
Option A: DNA Polymerase leads to synthesizing DNA from DNA (Replication of DNA).

Option B: RNA polymerase leads to synthesis of RNA from DNA (transcription).

Option C: Peptidyl transferase is an enzyme that leads to synthesis of protein (translation).

Option D: reverse transcriptase is RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, a class of enzymes capable of synthesizing a single-stranded and then a dsDNA molecule from a single-stranded RNA template. It exists in retroviruses.

The genetic material for some animal and plant viruses is RNA rather than DNA. Although some RNA viruses never have their information transcribed into a DNA molecule, many animal RNA viruses-specifically, the retroviruses (eg, the human immunodeficiency, or HIV virus)-are transcribed by viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, the so-called reverse transcriptase, to produce a double-stranded DNA copy of their RNA genome. In many cases, the resulting double-stranded DNA transcript is integrated into the host genome and subsequently serves as a template for gene expression and from which new viral RNA genomes and viral mRNAs can be transcribed.

questions.text: Number of ATP formed by oxidation of one molecule of palmitic acid (16 c):
questions.solution:
Energetics of Beta Oxidation

The number of ATPs obtained depends on the number of Carbon atoms in the fatty acid from Beta oxidation of Palmitic acid (C-16)

First calculate how many cycles of beta oxidation [(n/2)-1] where n = no of carbon atoms

  • In case of palmitic acid, 7 cycles of beta oxidation
  • From one cycle of beta oxidation
  • 1 FADH2 = 1.5 ATPs
  • 1 NADH = 2.5 ATPs
  • Total = 4 ATPs
  • From 7 cycles of beta oxidation
  • 7 × No of ATPs from 1 cycle
  • 7 × 4 = 28 ATPs

In case of Palmitic Acid (16/2) = 8 Acetyl CoA

  • From one Acetyl CoA by TCA Cycle 10 ATPs
  • From 8 Acetyl CoA
  • 8 × 10 = 80 ATPs
  • Total ATPs from Palmitic Acid = 28 + 80 = 108
  • 2 ATPs utilized for initial activation of Fatty Acid
  • So net ATPs from Palmitic Acid = 108-2 = 106 ATPs.

choices.text: Excess dietary Vit. D causes toxicity
Prolonged exposure to sunlight can cause formation of excess active compounds
Excess Vit. D can cause contracture of blood vessels causing high blood pressure

questions.text: False regarding Vit. D toxicity is?
questions.solution:
• Excess Vit. D is the most toxic vitamin when taken in excess as it causes abnormal calcification of soft tissues.
  • Excess Vit. Dcan lead to contraction of blood vessels, high blood pressure, and calcinosis-the calcification of soft tissues.
  • In at least a few cases, hypercalcemia in response to low intakes of vitamin D is due to genetic defects of calcidiol 24-hydroxylase, the enzyme that leads to inactivation of the vitamin.
  • Although excess dietary vitamin D is toxic, excessive exposure to sunlight does not lead to vitamin D poisoning, because there is a limited capacity to form the precursor, 7-dehydrocholesterol, and prolonged exposure of previtamin D to sunlight leads to formation of inactive compounds.

choices.text: Tryptophan deficiency can lead to pellagra
Males are affected more than females
It is characterized by photosensitive dermatitis

questions.text: All the following sentences are true about pellagra, except:
questions.solution:
• Although the nutritional etiology of pellagra is well established, and either tryptophan or niacin prevents or cures the disease, additional factors, including deficiency of riboflavin or vitamin B6, both of which are required for synthesis of nicotinamide from tryptophan, may be important.
  • A number of genetic diseases that result in defects of tryptophan metabolism are associated with the development of pellagra, despite an apparently adequate intake of both tryptophan and niacin.
  • Hartnup disease is a rare genetic condition in which there is a defect of the membrane transport mechanism for tryptophan, resulting in large losses as a result of intestinal malabsorption and failure of renal reabsorption.
  • In carcinoid syndrome, there is metastasis of a primary liver tumor of enterochromaffin cells, which synthesize 5-hydroxytryptamine. Overproduction of 5-hydroxytryptamine may account for as much as 60% of the body's tryptophan metabolism, causing pellagra because of the diversion away from NAD synthesis.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Pellagra is caused by the deficiency of both Tryptophan & Niacin.

Option C: In most outbreaks of pellagra, women are affected more than men, probably the result of inhibition of tryptophan metabolism by estrogen metabolites.

Option D: Pellagra is characterized by photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhoea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

questions.text: Which of the following is acting as a Phosphagens in vertebrate skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
• Phosphagens act as storage forms of group transfer potential and include creatine phosphate, which occurs in vertebrate skeletal muscle, heart, spermatozoa, and brain, and arginine phosphate, which occurs in invertebrate muscle.
  • When ATP is rapidly being utilized as a source of energy for muscular contraction, phosphagens permit its concentrations to be maintained, but when the ATP/ADP ratio is high, their concentration can increase to act as an energy store.

So Option A is correct option.

Option A: Creatine phosphate acts as phosphagens in vertebrate skeletal muscle.

Option B: Arginine phosphate act as phosphagens in invertebrate muscle.

Option C & Option D: Glucose 6 phosphate and fructose 6 phosphate not act as Phosphagens.

questions.text: Amino acid sequence is not found by:
questions.solution:
Methods of Protein Sequencing Sanger's Technique

  • Sanger's Reagent is 1, Fluoro 2, 4 Dinitrobenzene
  • Sanger's Reagent derivatizes the amino terminal residues.
  • The first Protein to be sequenced by the method is Insulin by Fredrick Sanger. He got Nobel prize in 1958.
  • Only dipeptides or tripeptides can be sequenced.

Edman's Technique

  • By using Edman's Reagent (Phenyl Iso-Thio-cyanate).
  • Phenyl Isothiocyanate derivatives the amino terminal of Polypeptide.
  • Edman's Technique can sequence many residues (5-30 residues) of a single polypeptide sample unlike Sanger's

questions.text: Which of the following is the major end product of nitrogen metabolism in humans?
questions.solution: Urea is the major end product of nitrogen catabolism in humans; humans are ureotelic.

questions.text: Dopamine hydroxylase catalyses the conversion of:
questions.solution:
Conversion of Tyrosine to Epinephrine involves 4 sequential steps -

  1. Ring Hydroxylation(Tyrosine → DOPA by Tyrosine hydroxylase)
  2. Decarboxylation(DOPA → Dopamine by DOPA decarboxylase)
  3. Side chain hydroxylation(Dopamine → Norepinephrine by Dopamine hydroxylase)
  4. N-Methylation (Norepinephrine → Epinephrine by PNMT)

questions.text: Which of the following is a Lyase?
questions.solution:
Some examples of Lyases are:

  • HMG CoA Lyase
  • Argininosuccinate Lyase
  • ATP Citrate Lyase
  • Aldolase
  • Fumarase.

questions.text: All of the following anticoagulants will chelate calcium and so inhibit coagulation, except:
questions.solution:
Option A, Option C, Option D: Different anticoagulants (citrate, EDTA or oxalate, all of which chelate calcium and so inhibit coagulation) are used for collection of plasma samples, depending on the assay to be performed.

Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, so inhibit coagulation.

For measurement of blood glucose, potassium fluoride is added, as an inhibitor of glycolysis by red blood cells.

questions.text: 5'-Nucleotidase is a marker for which of the following membrane?
questions.solution:
Membranes contain many proteins, some of which have enzymatic activity. Some of these enzymes are located only in certain membranes and can therefore be used as markers to follow the purification of these membranes

Option A: The marker enzyme for inner mitochondrial membrane is ATP synthase.

Option B: 5'-Nucleotidase, Adenyl cyclase, Na - K ATPase are markers of plasma membranes.

Option C: The marker of membrane present in Endoplasmic reticulum is Glucose 6 phosphatase.

Option D: The markers of membrane present in Golgi apparatus are Sialyl transferase, Galactosyl transferase, Golgi mannosidase II, GlcNAc transferase

questions.text: The enzyme protein kinase A is activated by:
questions.solution:
• In eukaryotic cells, cAMP binds to a protein kinase called protein kinase A (PKA), a heterotetrameric molecule consisting of two regulatory subunits (R) that inhibit the activity of the two catalytic subunits (C) when bound as a tetrameric complex. cAMP binding to the R2C2 tetramer results in the following reaction:
    • 4cAMP + R2C2 ⇔ R2 - 4cAMP + 2C
  • The R2C2 complex has no enzymatic activity, but the binding of cAMP to the R subunit induces dissociation of the R-C complex, thereby activating the latter. The active C subunit catalyzes the transfer of the γ phosphate of ATP to a serine or threonine residue in a variety of proteins. The consensus PKA phosphorylation sites are -ArgArg/ Lys-X-Ser/Thr- and -Arg-Lys-X-X-Ser-, where X can be any amino acid.

So, enzyme protein kinase A is activated by cAMP (Option C), not by cGMP (Option B), calcium (Option A) or ATP (Option D).

questions.text: The enzyme not involved in substrate level phosphorylation:
questions.solution:
• Substrate Level Phosphorylation: ATP can be produced at substrate level without mediation of electron transport chain.
  • Reaction, catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase, phosphate is transferred from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate onto ADP, forming ATP (substrate-level phosphorylation) and 3-phosphoglycerate.
  • The phosphate of phosphoenolpyruvate is transferred to ADP in another substrate-level phosphorylation catalyzed by pyruvate kinase to form two molecules of ATP per molecule of glucose oxidized.
  • Succinyl-CoA is converted to succinate by the enzyme succinate thiokinase (succinyl-CoA synthetase). This is the only example of substrate level phosphorylation in the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most powerful technique used in transcription factor research which allows identifying genome wide DNA binding sites for transcription factors?
questions.solution:
Option A: Systematic deletion mapping is genetic mapping technique that enables to determine the location of specific genes on chromosomes.

Option B: DNAse I sensitivity assay used for discovering regulatory domains. This method maps discrete sites in the genome where the conformation of chromatin renders its DNA hypersensitive to cleavage by endonuclease DNAse I.

Option C: Chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing (ChIP-seq) is used for simultaneous identification of all of the genomic sites bound by a given transcription factor under a given set of physiologic conditions

Option D: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes that bind to only particular parts of a nucleic acid sequence with high degree of sequence complementarity.

questions.text: An isoenzyme variant of the following enzymes appear during pregnancy
questions.solution:
• Physically distinct forms of the same enzymes, but catalyse the same reaction
  • Different molecular forms of the same enzyme synthesized from the same or various tissues.

Isoenzymes of Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
